abstract.p: Heat shock proteins (HSPs) and HSP70-HSP90 organizing proteins (HOPs) are related, and they function together to maintain cellular homeostasis and respond to stress. In the present study, we reported the first molecular characteristics of HSP70 (designated as CeHSP70) and HOP (designated as CeHOP) genes from the freshwater green algae Closterium ehrenbergii and examined the changes in their expression profiles under heat stress and toxic chemicals treatment. CeHSP70 presented the conserved motif patterns and EEVD domain specific to cytosolic HSP70; CeHOP contained a typical domain of TPR repeats. Real-time PCR analysis showed that thermal stress considerably up-regulated both CeHOP and CeHSP70. In addition, the genes were significantly induced by CuCl 2 , CuSO 4 , and NiSO , but not by K Cr 2 O 7 , herbicide, and endocrine disrupting chemicals. These results suggest that CeHOP and CeHSP70 function together and play a role in responses to specific stressors and indicate their possible use as sensitive specific biomarkers in risk assessments.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The unicellular green algae Closterium ehrenbergii is widely distributed in freshwater ecosystems throughout the world (Ichimura and Kasai 1984); it is known to sensitively respond to a wide range of pollutants, and its sensitivity and sublethal toxicity have been assessed using heavy metals and disinfectant (Juneau et al. 2003;Sathasivam et al. 2016). Our recent works on the species have shown that antioxidant SOD and small HSPs respond sensitively when exposed to heavy metals (Wang et al. 2017(Wang et al. , 2018Abassi et al. 2019;Wang and Ki 2019). These results suggest that it can be used as a molecular toxicity testing model; however, little research has been conducted regarding molecular gene responses to toxic substances.

Heat shock proteins 70 (HSP70) are a family of conserved ubiquitously expressed proteins, and they are an important part of the cell's machinery for protein folding and help protect cells from stress (Morano 2007). To date, HSP70 genes and proteins have been studied in most organisms, including microalgae Dunaliella salina and Prorocentrum minimum Mosaviazam et al. 2016). In addition, molecular studies showed that HSP70 genes are mostly induced by environmental stresses and toxic chemicals (Piano et al. 2004;, and thus they have been considered as potential biomarkers for ecotoxicogenomics assessments in different organisms (Wepener et al. 2005).

HSP70-HSP90 organizing protein (HOP) regulates and assists the major chaperones (Odunuga et al. 2004). It is recognized by the presence of three TPR domains, which are tandem repeats of a 34-amino-acid consensus motif, forming a cleft of seven antiparallel α-helices facilitating the binding to C-terminal tails of HSP90 and HSP70 (Schmid et al. 2012). This suggests that the HOP may react simultaneously with HSP70 and/or HSP90, in a coupled response against stress conditions. Here, we characterized HSP70 and HOP genes from C. ehrenbergii, and examined the changes in their transcriptional responses, following heat stress and different chemical treatments, to understand their roles in cell stress defense and their potential application as biomarkers for environmental pollution monitoring.

div.head: Materials and methods
div.p: Algae culture, RNA extraction, and cDNA synthesis A strain of Closterium ehrenbergii (Ce-01) was obtained from Environmental Bio Inc. (Seoul, Korea). The cells were cultured in C medium (Watanebe 2000) at 20 ± 1°C, with 12:12 h light-dark cycle and a photon flux density of 65 μmol photons/m 2 /s. Total RNA extraction and cDNA synthesis were conducted following our previous studies (Abassi et al. 2019;Wang and Ki 2019).

div.head: Sequence identity and phylogenetic analysis
div.p: The full length cDNA sequences of CeHOP and CeHSP70 genes were identified from an Expressed Sequence Tag (EST) library of C. ehrenbergii in our laboratory and validated by PCR with specific primers (Supplementary Table 1). PCR reaction conditions were as follows: pre-denaturation at 94°C for 3 min; 39 cycles of 94°C for 30 s, 55°C for 30 s, 72°C for 2 min, and extension at 72°C for 10 min. Positive PCR products were purified, cloned into pMD20-T vectors (Takara, Shiga, Japan), transformed into Escherichia coli competent cells, and subjected to DNA sequencing (Sanger method). Protein motifs and conserved domains of CeHOP and CeHSP70 were analyzed according to the method in our previous study (Abassi et al. 2019).

div.head: Stress treatment
div.p: Exponential growth phase cultures (200 mL) with an original cell density of 3.0 ± 0.25 × 10 cells/mL were used for stress treatment. For thermal treatments, we exposed the cultures to 20°C (control), 24, 28, 32, and 36°C, and then harvested the cells after 30 min. For chemical treatments, a series of separate doses were added to cultures to reach the following final concentrations: 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, and 0.5 mg/L of copper chloride (CuCl 2 , Cat. No. 222011, Sigma-Aldrich); 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, and 0.5 mg/L of copper sulfate (CuSO 4 , Cat. No. C1297, Sigma-Aldrich); 0.1, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, and 5.0 mg/L of nickel sulfate (NiSO 4 , Cat. No. 10101-97-0, Sigma-Aldrich); 1.0, 2.0, 3.0, and 4.0 mg/L of potassium dichromate (K 2 Cr 2 O 7 , Cat. No. 7778-50-9, Sigma-Aldrich); 0.05, 0.3, and 0.8 mg/L of atrazine (C 8 H 14 ClN 5 , Cat.No.45330, Sigma-Aldrich); 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4, and 0.5 mg/L of polychlorinated biphenyl (C 12 H 10 − x Cl x , PCB, Aroclor 1016, Cat. No. 48701, Sigma-Aldrich); and 0.1, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, and 2.0 mg/L of endosulfan (C 9 H 6 Cl 6 O 3 S, Cat. No. 1031-07-8, Sigma-Aldrich). Atrazine was dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) to obtain a stock solution and the maximum amount of DMSO was 0.01% in all test cultures, as the concentration (0.01%) of DMSO has no effect on the organism (Kim et al. 2020). The tested concentrations of individual chemicals were based on the EC 50 values meas Table 2). All samples were performed in triplicate and all dilutions were prepared from standard stock solutions.

Reactive oxygen species (ROS) measurement
div.p: Cells were independently treated with 0.2 mg/L CuSO , 0.5 mg/L CuCl 2 , 4 mg/L K 2 Cr 2 O 7 , and 0.1 mg/L atrazine, for an incubation period of 24 h, stained using dihydroxyrhodamine 123 (DHR123-D1054; Sigma-Aldrich) DHR123 at a final concentration of 20 μM for 1 h, then harvested by centrifugation and cleaned twice with fresh C medium. The cultures were then re-suspended in fresh C medium, and mounted onto a slide and sealed; green emission was observed with a fluorescence microscope (Carl Zeiss Axioskop, Oberkochen, Germany) to determine the level of ROS production in the cells and relative ROS levels were quantified with ImageJ software (NIH, Bethesda, MD) from the fluorescence microscopic images.

div.head: Real-time PCR and gene expression analysis
div.p: Quantitative real-time PCR was performed using a CFX96 Real-time PCR detection system (Bio-Rad, Hercules, CA). To assess the expression of HSP90, a sequence was selected from the EST library of C. ehrenbergii (Access. No. MT324120) and the primers were designed accordingly ( Supplementary Table 1). A reaction mixture for each PCR run was prepared using the TOPreal qPCR 2X PreMIX (SYBR Green) Kit (Enzynomics, Daejeon, Korea). The cycle parameters were as follows: preincubation (for UDG) of 4 min at 50°C, initial denaturation of 10 min at 95°C, followed by 39 cycles of 95°C for 10 s, 60°C for 15 s, and 72°C for 15 s; a dissociation step was included: 62°C for 2 s and 95°C for 20 s. All reactions were amplified in three technical replicates and the average values were calculated. Alpha tubulin (TUA), actin (ACT), and histone H4 were used as an internal control (Lee et al. 2015). The relative quantification of gene expressions among the treatment groups was analyzed using the cycle threshold (Ct) method (Livak and Schmittgen 2001), where Ct is the cycle number at which the fluorescent signal rises statistically above the background. All data were analyzed using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA), followed by the Student-Newman-Keuls multiple comparison test to compare the relative gene expression levels. P < 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

div.head: Results and discussion
div.p: Molecular characterization and phylogeny of CeHSP70 and HOP CeHSP70 cDNA (Access. No. MT324118) was 2181 bp in length, including a 99 bp 5′-untranslated region (UTR), a 114 bp 3′-UTR, and an open reading frame (ORF) of 1968 bp that encoded 655 amino acids (aa) ( Supplementary Fig. 1a). We identified three HSP70 protein family signatures:
div.formula: G I D L G T T Y S C , I F D L G G G T F D V S L L , a n d IVLVGGSTRIPKVQQ.
div.p: The structural comparisons of our CeHSP70 conformed to the conserved features of the HSP70 family of other organisms (Vayssier et al. 1999). We also detected an EEVD motif, which is a C-terminus conserved motif exclusively found in cytosolic HSPs (Vayssier et al. 1999;Assimon et al. 2015). Similar features of HSP70s were observed in other microalgae (Guo et al. , 2013(Guo et al. , 2015, suggesting that our protein is a cytosolic HSP70.

CeHOP cDNA (Access. No. MT324119) was 2165 bp long, comprising an ORF of 1749 bp, 143 bp 5′-UTR, and 272 bp 3′ UTR; it encoded a protein of 582 aa ( Supplementary Fig. 2a). The BLAST searches showed that our protein belongs to the tetratricopeptide-like helical domain superfamily, and we identified three TPR domains ( Supplementary Fig. 2c), which are the signature domains of the HOP family (Röhl et al. 2015). This matched with previous reports on HOP family proteins (Baindur-Hudson et al. 2015). Significant differences between the control and treated sample, as determined by one-way ANOVA, are highlighted *P < 0.05; **P < 0.01; ***P < 0.001 Phylogenetic analysis of CeHSP70 and CeHOP proteins showed that the green algae C. ehrenbergii clustered with species from the streptophytes, showing closer relativity with higher plants than with other green algae ( Supplementary Fig. 1b, Supplementary Fig. 2b). All the results combined confirm that the sequence we isolated in this study certainly belongs to the HOP family.

div.head: Effect of heat stress on HSP70, HSP90, and HOP expression
div.p: The results showed a correlation in the expression of both genes, with an up-regulated response to the different heat treatments (24°C, 28°C, 32°C, and 36°C) (Fig. 1). CeHOP showed a consistent up-regulation of~2.5-fold, with a highest up-regulation of 3-fold at 36°C; similarly, HOP transcripts increased with increasing temperatures in the soybean Glycine max (Zhang et al. 2003). CeHSP70 showed an up-regulated response in a temperature dependent manner, with approximately 2-fold changes at both 28°C and 32°C and 3-fold changes at 36°C when compared to the control (20°C). The expression levels of CeHSP90 showed an up-regulation similar to that observed for HSP70, in a temperature dependent manner, with a maximum of 4.5-fold changes at the highest temperature. These results were in accordance with heat responsive patterns of HSP70 and HSP90 in other microalgae (Rosic et al. 2011;Guo et al. , 2013Guo et al. , 2015. These suggest that CeHSP70 and CeHSP90 may have a role in the first line of defense against thermal fluctuations in the environments. Therefore, the HOP (since it is the organizing protein for HSP70/HSP90 and an important element in the activity of both HSP70 and HSP90) may be a key element of thermo-resistance in C. ehrenbergii. Figure 2 shows the response of HSP70, HSP90, and HOP upon treatments with different concentrations of toxic metals. Copper and nickel treated cells in exponential cultures showed a general up-regulation in the response of all tested genes. CuCl 2 treatments resulted in an up-regulation of both genes, with a more significant response for HOP with increased concentration; the response was up to 17-fold changes at 0.2 mg/L and decreased but still demonstrated significant 12-fold changes at a concentration of 0.5 mg/L (Fig. 2a). CuSO 4 treatments showed a continuous up-regulation of CeHOP in a concentration-dependent manner with the highest transcriptional changes of 10.5-fold compared to the control. CeHSP70 and CeHSP90 transcripts increased for lower concentrations of 0.05 and 0.1 mg/L, with 5-fold changes for CeHSP90 at a concentration of 0.2 mg/L, and a decrease in transcription nearing that of the control for CeHSP70 at higher concentrations (0.2 and 0.5 mg/L) and 3fold changes for CeHSP90 at 0.5 mg/L (Fig. 2b). CeHSP70 showed a down-regulation at low concentrations of K 2 Cr 2 O 7 (1 and 2 mg/L) and a slight increase in the transcription of the Fig. 3 Effect of atrazine (a), endosulfan (b), and PCB (c) on the expression of CeHOP, CeHSP70, and CeHSP90. Error bars represent the standard deviation. Significant differences between the control and treated sample, as determined by one-way ANOVA, are highlighted *P < 0.05 gene at concentrations of 3 and 4 mg/L. CeHSP90 transcripts increased by 1.7-fold and 1.9-fold changes at concentrations of 3 and 4 mg/L, respectively. CeHOP was induced with a marginally significant (P < 0.05) change of 1.8-fold at the highest concentration of 4 mg/L (Fig. 2d). These results were in accordance with a previous study regarding C. ehrenbergii small HSPs genes, which were induced in response to copper stress and showed no apparent changes to chromium treatments (Abassi et al. 2019). HOP, HSP70, and CeHSP90 showed high responses to different chemical treatments at concentrations lower than the EC 50 ; our genes were induced at 0.05 mg/L of CuCl 2 and CuSO 4 when the EC 50 for both chemicals were previously reported to be 0.24 mg/L and 0.20 mg/L, respectively (Supplementary Table 2). EC 50 for nickel sulfate was 1.53 mg/L and both HSP70 and CeHSP90 were induced at a concentration of 0.1 mg/L. The overall results showed high sensitivity toward certain chemicals but not others for HSP70, HSP90, and HOP, suggesting they might be involved in the early responses for certain stresses, making them perfect candidates as sensitive specific biomarkers for risk assessments.

div.head: Effect of heavy metals on HSP70, HSP90, and HOP expression
Effect of EDCs stress on HSP70, HSP90, and HOP expression
div.p: The tested EDCs had no apparent effects on the expression of HOP, HSP70, and HSP90 (Fig. 3). The genes showed no Fig. 4 Reactive oxygen species (ROS) production and relative ROS level in C. ehrenbergii after exposure to different contaminants; a Control (untreated cells), b 0.2 mg/L CuSO 4 , c 0.5 mg/L CuCl 2 , d 4 mg/L K 2 Cr 2 O 7 , and e 0.1 mg/L atrazine significant response for all treatments, except for PCB where HSP70 and HSP90 showed a rather significant response (P < 0.05) with 1.7-fold changes at 0.5 mg/L and 2-fold changes at 0.3 mg/L, respectively (Fig. 3c). HSP90 responded to PCB concentrations lower than the EC 50 , suggesting that it might be involved in early processes that counter PCB stress in C. ehrenbergii. EDCs such as PCB and endosulfan have the potential to cause oxidative stress by ROS generation (Shao et al. 2012). The toxic effect of ECDs has been extensively studied in higher organisms and recent studies showed that they also have toxic effects on microalgae even if these are considered as non-target organisms (Liu et al. 2010;Ki 2012, 2016). Microarray analysis of dinoflagellate Prorocentrum minimum by PCB exposure showed different responses from various genes involved in different cell pathways, suggesting that the EDC did not cause chloroplast and oxidative damage, but could lead to cell cycle arrest and apoptosis (Wang et al. 2018). We did not observe any effect of the EDCs on the transcriptional response of CeHOP and CeHSP70 of C. ehrenbergii. Similarly, our previous studies on P. minimum HSP90 and D. brightwellii HSP70 and HSP90 showed that these genes did not respond to EDCs (Guo et al. , 2013. The overall results suggest that HSPs genes, and consequently HOP, have no major role in the EDC stress response of C. ehrenbergii.

div.head: Oxidative stress with ROS accumulation
div.p: Following the results of metals and EDCs stress, we confirmed whether the stress treatments had an effect on C. ehrenbergii or not (Fig. 4). Copper sulfate is known to induce high ROS production in C. ehrenbergii (Wang et al. 2017), and our results confirmed the production of ROS at different concentrations of CuSO 4 and CuCl . The toxic effect of various metals and EDCs was indicated by ROS production, representing oxidative stress in C. ehrenbergii. These results proved that EDCs had an effect on the treated cells, and that our genes indeed had no apparent role in the counter against EDCs stress Wang et al. 2018).

The cooperation between CeHOP and CeHSPs in C. ehrenbergii can be implied by the correlation of their respective expression responses to various stress treatments. This suggests that HOP may react simultaneously with HSP70 and HSP90 in a coupled response as a defense against certain stress conditions (Lamoth et al. 2015).

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: The present study is intended to support previous results regarding the high sensitivity of C. ehrenbergii to various toxic chemicals, making it a model species for ecotoxicology research (Wang et al. 2017;Abassi et al. 2019;Wang and Ki 2019). CeHOP, CeHSP70, and CeHSP90 showed a coupled response to different stresses; however, the over-expression of the HOP gene over that of HSP70 and HSP90 suggests it might be involved in much more than the co-chaperone activity for the HSP70/HSP90 complex. HSPs genes have been already suggested as biomarkers in microalgae (Chankova et al. 2013;Guo et al. 2013); thus, HOP might be used as a biomarker to predict the action of species, and collect data of various genes transcriptions to design a response profile to external stress factors, which might help in the protection and monitoring of aquatic environments. This is the first study to evaluate the expression profiles of HSP70, HSP90, and HOP together in microalgae, and to our knowledge, there are no reports on the characterization of HOP genes from green algae. Therefore, this study has paved a way for further studies regarding the complex HOP/HSP70/HSP90 to understand the interaction between these genes and their mode of action, and especially to elucidate the roles of HOP in stress responses.
